John_Prine:
{{Short description|American singer-songwriter (1946–2020)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2020}} {{About|the musician|his debut album|John Prine (album)}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = John Prine | image = John Prine by Ron Baker.jpg | image_size = | caption = Prine at MerleFest 2006 | landscape = yes | background = solo_singer | birth_name = John Edward Prine | birth_date = {{Birth date|1946|10|10}} | death_date = {{Death date and age|2020|04|07|1946|10|10}} | birth_place = [[Maywood, Illinois]], U.S. | death_place = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], U.S. | instrument = {{hlist|Vocals|guitar}} | genre = {{Hlist|[[Country folk|Country-folk]]|[[progressive country]]{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1973/07/22/archives/its-so-progressive-in-texas-progressive-in-texas.html |title=It's So 'Progressive' in Texas |last=Carr |first=Patrick |date=July 22, 1973 |work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=2023-07-22}}|[[Americana (music)|Americana]]}} | occupation = {{hlist|Singer-songwriter}} | years_active = 1969–2020 | label = {{hlist|[[Atlantic Records|Atlantic]]|[[Asylum Records|Asylum]]|[[Oh Boy Records|Oh Boy]]|[[Rhino Records|Rhino]]}} | associated_acts = {{hlist|[[Steve Goodman]]|[[Iris DeMent]]}} | spouse = Fiona Prine (m. 1996) | website = {{URL|johnprine.com|JohnPrine.com}} }} '''John Edward Prine'''{{Cite web|url=https://www.dignitymemorial.com/obituaries/nashville-tn/john-prine-9116778|title = John Prine Obituary - Nashville, TN}} ({{IPAc-en|p|r|ai|n}}; October 10, 1946 – April 7, 2020) was an American singer-songwriter of [[country folk|country-folk music]]. Widely cited as one of the most influential songwriters of his generation, Prine was known for his signature blend of humorous lyrics about love, life, and current events, often with elements of [[social commentary]] and [[satire]], as well as sweet songs and melancholy ballads. He was active as a composer, recording artist, live performer, and occasional actor from the early 1970s until his death. Born and raised in [[Maywood, Illinois]], Prine learned to play the guitar at age 14. He attended classes at Chicago's [[Old Town School of Folk Music]].{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/oldtownschool/status/989572224213450752 |title=John Prine OTSFM Registration Card |publisher=Old Town School of Folk Music |date=September 17, 1964 |access-date=April 26, 2018}} After serving in [[West Germany]] with the [[U.S. Army]], he returned to Chicago in the late 1960s, where he worked as a mailman, writing and singing songs first as a hobby. Continuing studies at the Old Town School, he performed at a student hang-out, the nearby Fifth Peg. A laudatory review by [[Roger Ebert]] put Prine on the map. Singer-songwriter [[Kris Kristofferson]] heard Prine at [[Steve Goodman]]'s insistence, and Kristofferson invited Prine to be his opening act. Prine released his [[John Prine (album)|eponymous debut album]] in 1971.{{cite magazine | url=https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/john-prine-songwriters-hall-of-fame-interview-8515459/ | title=John Prine Shares the Remarkable 'Cinderella Story' of How His Career Got Started | magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] }} Featuring such songs as [[Paradise (John Prine song)|"Paradise"]], [[Sam Stone (song)|"Sam Stone"]] and "[[Angel from Montgomery]]", it has been hailed as one of the greatest of all albums.{{Cite web |title=#149 John Prine, 'John Prine' (1971) |url=https://www.rs500albums.com/150-101/149 |access-date=2023-10-10 |website=Rolling Stone 500 Greatest Albums Of All Time |language=en-US}} The acclaim Prine earned from his debut led to three more albums for Atlantic. ''[[Common Sense (John Prine album)|Common Sense]]'' (1975) was his first to chart on the Billboard U.S. Top 100. He then recorded three albums with [[Asylum Records]]. In 1981, he co-founded [[Oh Boy Records]], an independent label which released all of his music up until his death. His final album, 2018's ''[[The Tree of Forgiveness]]'', debuted at #5 on the [[Billboard 200]], his highest ranking on the charts. Prine struggled with health issues throughout his life, surviving cancer twice. He died in 2020 from complications caused by {{nowrap|[[COVID-19]]}}. Earlier the same year, he received the [[Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award]]. ==Early life== Prine was the son of William Mason Prine, a [[Tool and die maker|tool-and-die]] maker, and Verna Valentine (Hamm), a homemaker, both originally from [[Muhlenberg County, Kentucky]]. He was born and raised in the Chicago suburb of Maywood.{{Cite news|last=Barry|first=Dan|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/10/arts/music/john-prine-endures-with-a-half-smile-and-a-song.html|title=John Prine Endures, With a Half-Smile and a Song|date=April 6, 2016|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=March 30, 2020|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200330175317/https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/10/arts/music/john-prine-endures-with-a-half-smile-and-a-song.html|archive-date=March 30, 2020|url-status=live}}{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zcAvBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA76 |title=John Prine: In Spite of Himself|first=Eddie|last=Huffman|date=March 15, 2015|page=76|publisher=[[University of Texas Press]]|isbn=9780292748224|via=Google Books}} In summers, they would go back to visit family near [[Paradise, Kentucky]].{{Cite news |url=https://studsterkel.wfmt.com/programs/john-prine-discusses-his-life-and-his-formation-music-0 |title=John Prine discusses his life and his formation in music |date=1975 |work=Studs Terkel Radio Archive |access-date=April 11, 2020 |publisher=WFMT and Chicago History Museum |language=en}} Prine started playing guitar at age 14, taught by his brother, David.{{cite web |url=http://www.shrout.co.uk/jpbackpage.html |title=John Prine Information |website=Shrout.co.uk |date=October 10, 1946 |access-date=March 15, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111006062927/http://www.shrout.co.uk/jpbackpage.html |archive-date=October 6, 2011 |url-status=live }} He attended classes at Chicago's [[Old Town School of Folk Music]], and graduated from [[Proviso East High School]] in [[Maywood, Illinois]]. He was a [[U.S. Postal Service]] mailman for five years and was drafted into the [[United States Army]] during the [[Vietnam War]], serving as a vehicle mechanic in [[West Germany]] before beginning his musical career in Chicago.{{cite news |title=John Prine, Grammy-winning singer-songwriter, dead at 73 from coronavirus complications |url=https://nypost.com/2020/04/07/john-prine-grammy-winning-singer-songwriter-dead-at-73-from-coronavirus/ |access-date=April 8, 2020 |newspaper=[[New York Post]] |date=April 7, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200408023213/https://nypost.com/2020/04/07/john-prine-grammy-winning-singer-songwriter-dead-at-73-from-coronavirus/ |archive-date=April 8, 2020 |url-status=live }} ==Chicago folk scene== In the late 1960s, while Prine was delivering mail, he began to sing his songs (often first written in his head on the mail route) at [[open mic]] nights at the Fifth Peg on [[Armitage Avenue]] in Chicago. The bar was a gathering spot for nearby [[Old Town School of Folk Music]] teachers and students. Prine was initially a spectator, reluctant to perform, but eventually did so in response to a "You think you can do better?" comment made to him by another performer.{{Cite news |last=Kot |first=Greg |url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-xpm-2010-02-28-ct-ae-0228-john-prine-20100228-story.html |title=John Prine recalls his Chicago folk roots |date=February 28, 2010 |work=Chicago Tribune |access-date=April 8, 2020 |language=en-US}} After his first open mic, he was offered paying gigs. In 1970, ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' film critic [[Roger Ebert]] heard Prine by chance at the Fifth Peg and wrote his first printed review, "Singing Mailman Who Delivers A Powerful Message In A Few Words":{{blockquote|He appears on stage with such modesty he almost seems to be backing into the spotlight. He sings rather quietly, and his guitar work is good, but he doesn't show off. He starts slow. But after a song or two, even the drunks in the room begin to listen to his lyrics. And then he has you....Prine's lyrics work with poetic economy to sketch a character in just a few words.{{cite news |url=http://www.rogerebert.com/balder-and-dash/john-prine-american-legend |title=Roger Ebert's Journal: "John Prine: American Legend" reprinting October 9, 1970 review|work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]] |access-date=February 23, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150223213137/http://www.rogerebert.com/balder-and-dash/john-prine-american-legend |archive-date=February 23, 2015 |url-status=live |date=14 November 2010}}}} After the review was published, Prine's popularity grew.{{cite web|url=https://ultimateclassicrock.com/john-prine-roger-ebert-first-review/|title=How an Unplanned Roger Ebert Review Launched John Prine's Career|last=Wilkening|first=Matthew|website=Ultimate Classic Rock|date=April 8, 2020 |language=en|access-date=April 8, 2020}} He became a central figure in the Chicago [[American folk music revival|folk revival]], which also included such singer-songwriters as [[Steve Goodman]], [[Michael Peter Smith]], [[Bonnie Koloc]], [[Jim Post]], [[Tom Dundee]], [[Anne Hills]], and [[Fred Holstein]]. Joined by such established musicians as [[Jethro Burns]] and [[Bob Gibson (musician)|Bob Gibson]], Prine performed frequently at a variety of Chicago clubs.{{cite web |title=John Prine obituary |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2020/apr/08/john-prine-obituary |website=[[The Guardian]] |date=April 8, 2020 |access-date=April 8, 2020}} He was offered a one-album deal of covers and with a few of his original songs, by [[Bob Koester]] from [[Delmark Records]], but decided the project was not right for him. In 1971, Prine was playing regularly at the Earl of Old Town. Steve Goodman, who was performing with [[Kris Kristofferson]] at another Chicago club, persuaded Kristofferson to go see Prine late one night.{{cite magazine |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/8515459/john-prine-songwriters-hall-of-fame-interview|title=John Prine Shares the Remarkable 'Cinderella Story' of How His Career Got Started|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=June 11, 2019|access-date=April 12, 2020}} Kristofferson later recalled, "By the end of the first line we knew we were hearing something else. It must've been like stumbling onto [[Bob Dylan|Dylan]] when he first busted onto the [[Greenwich Village|Village]] scene."{{Cite magazine |last1=Betts |first1=Stephen L. |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/john-prine-obit-253684/ |title=John Prine, One of America's Greatest Songwriters, Dead at 73 |date=April 8, 2020 |magazine=Rolling Stone |access-date=April 11, 2020 |last2=Doyle |first2=Patrick |language=en-US |last3=Doyle |first3=Patrick}} ==Recording career== === 1970s === Prine's [[John Prine (album)|eponymous debut album]] was released in 1971. Kristofferson (who once remarked that Prine wrote songs so good that "we'll have to break his thumbs"{{cite news|last=Chilton|first=Martin|title=John Prine: I Find the Human Condition Funny|work=Daily Telegraph|date=February 8, 2013|access-date=April 12, 2020|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/rockandpopfeatures/9853440/John-Prine-I-find-the-human-condition-funny.html |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20220111/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/rockandpopfeatures/9853440/John-Prine-I-find-the-human-condition-funny.html |archive-date=January 11, 2022 |url-access=subscription |url-status=live}}{{cbignore}}) invited Prine and Goodman to open for him at [[The Bitter End]] in New York City. In the audience was [[Jerry Wexler]], who signed Prine to [[Atlantic Records]] the next day. The album included Prine's signature songs "Illegal Smile" and [[Sam Stone (song)|"Sam Stone"]]. "Sam Stone" is about the trauma of a Vietnam veteran. He explained in 2011:
I knew there were a lot of GIs out there, who came out of the war and they weren’t quite right. … I knew there were homes where nobody was talking to each other, which became "[[Angel from Montgomery]]". … I knew there were kids who didn’t have fathers, and nobody ever acknowledged it, which became "6 O’Clock News."… I saw all that. I knew, and I couldn’t figure out why no one would say anything.{{cite web| title=Remembering John Prine, the Singing Mailman| date=April 7, 2021| work=[[National Postal Museum]]| url=https://postalmuseum.si.edu/remembering-john-prine-the-singing-mailman}}
[[Paradise (John Prine song)|"Paradise"]] is about the effects of [[surface mining]] on his parents' hometown of [[Paradise, Kentucky]]. The album also featured "Hello in There", a song about aging that was later covered by numerous artists, and "Far From Me", a lonely [[waltz]] about lost love for a waitress, which Prine later said was his favorite of all his songs. The album received many positive reviews, and some hailed Prine as "the next Dylan". Bob Dylan himself appeared unannounced at one of Prine's first New York City club appearances, anonymously backing him on harmonica.{{cite book |last1=Huffman |first1=Eddie |title=John Prine: In Spite of Himself |date=2015 |publisher=[[University of Texas Press]] |isbn=9780292748224 |pages=69–70 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zcAvBgAAQBAJ |access-date=April 7, 2020 |quote=''Rolling Stone'' caught up with Prine in New York shortly before the album's release [referring to ''Diamonds in the Rough'']. The opening paragraph of Ed McCormack's story described Prine on stage at the Bitter End, halfway through a six-night stand, calling out for a special guest: 'Whar's that harmonica player?' The 'nervously nondescript figure' who joined him was none other than Bob Dylan.}} Prine's second album, ''[[Diamonds in the Rough (album)|Diamonds in the Rough]]'' (1972), was a surprise for many after the critical success of his first LP; it was an uncommercial, stripped-down affair that reflected Prine's fondness for [[bluegrass music]] and features songs reminiscent of [[Hank Williams]]. Highlights of the compilation include the allegorical "[[The Great Compromise (song)|The Great Compromise]]", which includes a recitation and addresses the [[Vietnam War]], and the ballad "Souvenirs", which Prine later recorded with Goodman.{{cite magazine |title=Looking Back on John Prine Buddy Steve Goodman |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-album-reviews/looking-back-on-john-prine-buddy-steve-goodman-860284/ |magazine=Rolling Stone |date=July 19, 2019 |access-date=April 8, 2020}} His subsequent albums from the 1970s include ''[[Sweet Revenge (John Prine album)|Sweet Revenge]]'' (1973), containing such fan favorites as "Dear Abby", "Grandpa Was a Carpenter", and "Christmas in Prison", and [[Common Sense (John Prine album)|''Common Sense'']] (1975), with "Come Back to Us Barbara Lewis Hare Krishna Beauregard". The latter album was Prine's first to chart on the U.S. Top 100 by ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' and reflected his growing commercial success. It was produced by Steve Cropper. ''[[Bruised Orange]]'' (1978) is a Steve Goodman–produced album that gave listeners songs such as "That's The Way That The World Goes 'Round", "Sabu Visits the Twin Cities Alone", "Fish and Whistle", and the title track.{{cite magazine |last1=Cocks |first1=Jay |title=Bruised Orange |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-album-reviews/bruised-orange-190100/ |magazine=Rolling Stone |date=September 7, 1978 |access-date=April 8, 2020}} In 1974, singer [[David Allan Coe]] achieved considerable success on the country charts with "[[You Never Even Called Me by My Name]]", co-written by Prine and Goodman. The song good-naturedly spoofs stereotypical country music lyrics to create what it calls "the perfect country and western song". Prine refused to take a songwriter's credit (stating he was too drunk when the song was written to remember what he had contributed) and Goodman received sole credit. Goodman bought Prine a [[jukebox]] as a gift from his publishing royalties.{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OMiLqHTvbKE|title=John Prine – You Never Even Call Me by My Name (1987)|date=June 11, 2015 |publisher=YouTube|access-date=October 4, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200228063135/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OMiLqHTvbKE&gl=US&hl=en&has_verified=1&bpctr=9999999999|archive-date=February 28, 2020|url-status=live}} In 1975, Prine toured the U.S. and Canada with a full band featuring guitarist [[Arlen Roth]].{{cite web |title=About Arlen Roth |url=https://www.arlenroth.com/about |website=www.arlenroth.com |access-date=April 8, 2020}} ''[[Pink Cadillac (album)|Pink Cadillac]]'' (1979) features two songs produced by [[Sun Records]] founder [[Sam Phillips]], who by this time rarely did any studio work. The song "Saigon" is about a [[Vietnam veteran]] traumatized by the war ("The static in my attic's gettin' ready to blow"). During the recording, one of the [[guitar amplifiers]] blew up (which is evident on the album).{{cite web |last1=Ramsey |first1=Jan |title=John Prine |url=http://www.offbeat.com/articles/john-prine/ |website=offbeat.com |date=December 2002 |publisher=Offbeat Magazine |access-date=April 8, 2020}} The other song Phillips produced is "How Lucky", about Prine's hometown.{{cite magazine |last1=Betts |first1=Stephen |title=Hear John Prine Update His 'Song of Personal Confrontation' 'How Lucky' |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/john-prine-how-lucky-amazon-music-723667/ |magazine=Rolling Stone |date=September 14, 2018 |access-date=April 8, 2020}} === 1980s === In 1981, rejecting the established model of the recording industry, which Prine felt exploited singers and songwriters, he co-founded the independent record label [[Oh Boy Records]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee]]. His fans, supporting the project, sent him enough money to cover the costs, in advance, of his next album. Prine continued writing and recording albums throughout the 1980s. His songs continued to be covered by other artists; the country supergroup [[The Highwaymen (country supergroup)|The Highwaymen]] recorded "The 20th Century Is Almost Over", written by Prine and Goodman. Steve Goodman died of [[leukemia]] in 1984 and Prine contributed four tracks to ''A Tribute to Steve Goodman'', including a cover version of Goodman's "My Old Man".{{cite news|last=Oermann|first=Robert K.|title=Sade's 'Promise' broken; Grace's is the 'Greatest'|newspaper=The Tennessean|date=January 12, 1986}} === 1990s === In 1991, Prine released the [[Grammy]]-winning ''[[The Missing Years (album)|The Missing Years]]'', his first collaboration with producer and [[Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers|Heartbreakers]] bassist [[Howie Epstein]]. The title song records Prine's humorous take on what Jesus did in the unrecorded years between his childhood and [[Ministry of Jesus|ministry]].{{cite magazine |last1=Milward |first1=John |title=The Missing Years |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-album-reviews/the-missing-years-92682/ |access-date=April 7, 2020 |magazine=Rolling Stone |date=January 23, 1992 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200408035952/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-album-reviews/the-missing-years-92682/ |archive-date=April 8, 2020 |url-status=live }}{{cite news |last1=Davis |first1=Noel |title=Finding Success in 'Missing Years' : Pop music: John Prine, who will perform at the Coach House, says the popularity of his latest album caught him by surprise. |url=https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-1992-07-07-ca-1761-story.html |access-date=April 7, 2020 |work=Los Angeles Times |date=July 7, 1992 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200408035952/https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-1992-07-07-ca-1761-story.html |archive-date=April 8, 2020 |url-status=live }}{{cite web |last1=Reid |first1=Graham |title=John Prine: The Missing Years (1991) |url=https://www.elsewhere.co.nz/essentialelsewhere/2043/john-prine-the-missing-years-1991/ |website=Elsewhere |access-date=April 7, 2020 |date=March 29, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200408040505/https://www.elsewhere.co.nz/essentialelsewhere/2043/john-prine-the-missing-years-1991/ |archive-date=April 8, 2020 |url-status=live }} In 1995, ''[[Lost Dogs and Mixed Blessings]]'' was released, another collaboration with Epstein.{{cite magazine |last1=Manning |first1=Kara |title=John Prine: 'It's Hard to Write a Happy Love Song' |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/john-prine-lost-dogs-mixed-blessings-album-interview-1995-191626/ |access-date=April 7, 2020 |magazine=Rolling Stone |date=September 21, 1995 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200408041204/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/john-prine-lost-dogs-mixed-blessings-album-interview-1995-191626/ |archive-date=April 8, 2020 |url-status=live }} On this album is the long track "Lake Marie", a partly spoken word song interweaving tales over decades centered on themes of "goodbye".{{Cite news |last=Coyle |first=Jake |url=https://oklahoman.com/article/5659790/essential-tracks-from-john-prine-folk-musics-mark-twain/ |title=Essential tracks from John Prine, folk music's Mark Twain |date=April 10, 2020 |work=The Oklahoman |access-date=April 11, 2020 |agency=Associated Press |language=en-US}} Bob Dylan later cited it as perhaps his favorite Prine song. Prine followed it up in 1999 with ''[[In Spite of Ourselves]]'', which was unusual for him in that it contained only one original song (the title track); the rest were covers of classic country songs. All of the tracks are duets with well-known female country vocalists, including [[Lucinda Williams]], [[Emmylou Harris]], [[Patty Loveless]], [[Dolores Keane]], [[Trisha Yearwood]], and [[Iris DeMent]].{{cite news |last1=Klein |first1=Joshua |title=John Prine: In Spite Of Ourselves |url=https://music.avclub.com/john-prine-in-spite-of-ourselves-1798193623 |access-date=April 7, 2020 |work=AV Club |date=March 29, 2002 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191106102513/https://music.avclub.com/john-prine-in-spite-of-ourselves-1798193623 |archive-date=November 6, 2019 |url-status=live }}{{cite web |last1=Spacek |first1=Nick |title=Vinyl Review: John Prine – In Spite of Ourselves |url=http://modern-vinyl.com/2016/09/19/vinyl-review-john-prine-in-spite-of-ourselves/ |website=Modern Vinyl |access-date=April 7, 2020 |date=September 19, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200408042004/http://modern-vinyl.com/2016/09/19/vinyl-review-john-prine-in-spite-of-ourselves/ |archive-date=April 8, 2020 |url-status=live }} === 2000s === Prine appeared in a supporting role in the [[Billy Bob Thornton]] movie ''[[Daddy & Them]]'' (2001). "In Spite of Ourselves" is played during the end credits.{{cite web |title=Daddy and Them (2001) |url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/daddy_and_them |website=Rotten Tomatoes |access-date=April 8, 2020}} Prine recorded a version of [[Stephen Foster]]'s "[[My Old Kentucky Home]]" in 2004 for the compilation album ''[[Beautiful Dreamer (album)|Beautiful Dreamer]]'', which won the Grammy for Best Traditional Folk Album.{{cite web |title=47th Annual GRAMMY Awards (2004) |url=https://www.grammy.com/grammys/awards/47th-annual-grammy-awards-2004 |website=www.grammy.com |date=November 28, 2017 |publisher=Grammy.com |access-date=April 8, 2020}} In 2005, Prine released his first all-new offering since ''Lost Dogs and Mixed Blessings'', the album ''[[Fair & Square (John Prine album)|Fair & Square]]'', which tended toward a more laid-back, acoustic approach. The album contains songs such as "Safety Joe", about a man who has never taken any risks in his life, and also "Some Humans Ain't Human", Prine's protest piece on the album, which talks about the ugly side of [[human nature]] and includes a quick shot at President [[George W. Bush]]. ''Fair & Square'' won the 2005 Grammy Award for Best Contemporary Folk Album. The album contains original songs plus two covers: [[A.P. Carter]]'s "Bear Creek Blues" and [[Blaze Foley]]'s "Clay Pigeons".{{cite web |title=48th Annual GRAMMY Awards (2005) |url=https://www.grammy.com/grammys/awards/48th-annual-grammy-awards |website=www.grammy.com |date=November 28, 2017 |publisher=Grammy.com |access-date=April 8, 2020}} === 2010s === On June 22, 2010, Oh Boy Records released a tribute album titled ''[[Broken Hearts & Dirty Windows: Songs of John Prine]].'' The album features members of the modern folk revival, including [[My Morning Jacket]], [[The Avett Brothers]], [[Conor Oberst and the Mystic Valley Band]], [[Old Crow Medicine Show]], [[Lambchop (band)|Lambchop]], [[Josh Ritter]], [[Drive-By Truckers]], [[Nickel Creek]]'s [[Sara Watkins]], [[Deer Tick (band)|Deer Tick]] featuring Liz Isenberg, [[Justin Townes Earle]], [[Those Darlins]], and [[Bon Iver]]'s [[Justin Vernon]].{{cite web |url=http://brokenheartsanddirtywindows.com/about.html |title=Broken Hearts and Dirty Windows: The Songs of John Prine; Oh Boy Records |website=Brokenheartsanddirtywindows.com |access-date=February 18, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120310090639/http://www.brokenheartsanddirtywindows.com/about.html |archive-date=March 10, 2012 |url-status=live }} [[File:John Prine (2016) (cropped).jpg|alt=Prine onstage with a guitar and a microphone|thumb|Prine onstage, 2016]] In 2016, Prine was named winner of the PEN/Song Lyrics Award, given to two songwriters every other year by the [[PEN International|PEN]] New England chapter. The 2016 award was shared with [[Tom Waits]] and his songwriting collaborator wife [[Kathleen Brennan]]. Judges for the award included [[Peter Wolf]], [[Rosanne Cash]], [[Paul Simon]], [[Elvis Costello]], and [[Bono]], as well as literary judges [[Salman Rushdie]], [[Natasha Tretheway]], and [[Paul Muldoon]].{{Cite web|url=https://pen.org/|title=Home|website=Pen.org|date=September 20, 2016|access-date=April 8, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170718155703/https://pen.org/|archive-date=July 18, 2017|url-status=live}}{{Cite web |url=https://www.elviscostello.com/ |title=I Was Speaking Today . . . |last=Costello |first=Elvis |date=April 13, 2020 |website=Elvis Costello |language=en |access-date=April 15, 2020}} In 2016, Prine released ''[[For Better, or Worse]]'', a follow-up to ''In Spite of Ourselves''. The album features country music covers spotlighting some of the most prominent female voices in the genre, including; [[Alison Krauss]], [[Kacey Musgraves]], and [[Lee Ann Womack]], as well as Iris DeMent, the only guest artist to appear on both compilation albums.{{cite web |last1=Davies |first1=Mike |title=John Prine: For Better, Or Worse |url=https://www.folkradio.co.uk/2016/09/john-prine-better-worse/ |website=Folk Radio |access-date=April 8, 2020 |date=September 29, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180510090043/http://www.folkradio.co.uk/2016/09/john-prine-better-worse/ |archive-date=May 10, 2018 |url-status=live }} On March 15, 2017, the American Currents exhibit opened at the [[Country Music Hall of Fame]]. The exhibit featured a pair of [[cowboy boots]] and jacket that Prine often wore on stage, his personal guitar, and the original handwritten lyric to his hit, "Angel From Montgomery". The American Currents Class of 2016 showcased artists who made a significant impact on country music in 2016, including, Prine. Prine won his second Artist of the Year award at the 2017 [[Americana Music Honors & Awards]] after previously winning in 2005.{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/john-prine-sturgill-simpson-triumph-at-2017-americana-honors-awards-198811/|title=John Prine, Sturgill Simpson Triumph at 2017 Americana Honors & Awards|last=Moss|first=Marissa R.|date=September 14, 2017|magazine=Rolling Stone|language=en-US|access-date=April 8, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200307184257/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/john-prine-sturgill-simpson-triumph-at-2017-americana-honors-awards-198811/|archive-date=March 7, 2020|url-status=live}} On February 8, 2018, Prine announced his first new album of original material in 13 years, titled ''[[The Tree of Forgiveness]]'', would be released on April 13. Produced by [[Dave Cobb]], the album was released on Prine's own Oh Boy Records and features guest artists Jason Isbell, [[Amanda Shires]], [[Dan Auerbach]], and [[Brandi Carlile]]. Alongside the announcement, Prine released the track "Summer's End".{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/sections/allsongs/2018/02/08/584219320/john-prine-to-release-his-first-album-of-new-songs-in-13-years |title=John Prine To Release His First Album Of New Songs in 13 Years |date=February 8, 2018 |work=[[NPR]] |first=Jacob |last=Ganz |access-date=February 9, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180208204744/https://www.npr.org/sections/allsongs/2018/02/08/584219320/john-prine-to-release-his-first-album-of-new-songs-in-13-years |archive-date=February 8, 2018 |url-status=live }} The album became Prine's highest-charting album on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]].{{cite magazine|url= https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/8366469/jason-aldean-scores-rearview-town-no-1-billboard-200|title= Jason Aldean Scores Fourth No. 1 on Billboard 200 Albums Chart With 'Rearview Town'|date= April 22, 2018|first= Keith|last= Caulfield|magazine= Billboard|access-date= April 23, 2018|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20180422221345/https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/8366469/jason-aldean-scores-rearview-town-no-1-billboard-200|archive-date= April 22, 2018|url-status= live}} In 2019, he recorded several tracks including "Please Let Me Go 'Round Again"—a song which warmly confronts the end of life—with longtime friend and compatriot [[Swamp Dogg]] in his final recording session.{{Cite magazine|last=Bernstein|first=Jonathan|date=April 8, 2020|title=Revisiting John Prine's Last Moment on Record|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/john-prine-last-recording-swamp-dogg-980433/|access-date=June 15, 2020|magazine=Rolling Stone|language=en-US}} ===Posthumous releases=== The last song Prine recorded before he died was "I Remember Everything", released on June 12, 2020, alongside a music video. It was released following the two-hour special tribute show, ''A Tribute Celebrating John Prine'' aired on June 11, 2020, which featured [[Sturgill Simpson]], [[Vince Gill]], [[Jason Isbell]], [[Kacey Musgraves]], [[Bonnie Raitt]], [[Rita Wilson]], [[Eric Church]], [[Brandi Carlile]] and many other country artists and friends.{{cite web|url=https://pitchfork.com/news/listen-to-john-prines-final-song-i-remember-everything/amp/|title=Listen to John Prine's Final Song "I Remember Everything"|work=[[Pitchfork (magazine)|Pitchfork]]|last=Minsker|first=Evan|date=June 12, 2020|access-date=July 2, 2020}} On the first night of the [[2020 Democratic National Convention]], Prine singing "I Remember Everything" was the soundtrack to the COVID-19 memorial video.{{Cite web|title=The Democratic National Convention used John Prine's last recording for a COVID-19 memorial video|url=https://news.yahoo.com/democratic-national-convention-used-john-042605465.html|access-date=2021-06-22|website=news.yahoo.com|date=August 18, 2020 |language=en-US}} == Personal life == Prine was married three times. His first marriage was to high-school sweetheart Ann Carole in 1966. The marriage lasted until the late 1970s. Prine was married to bassist Rachel Peer from 1984 to 1988. Prine met Fiona Whelan, who later became his manager, in 1988.{{Cite web|url=https://apnews.com/e96aea5d3a1d9dd2c27ebeb88a61df28|title=John Prine in critical condition with COVID-19 symptoms|date=March 29, 2020|website=AP NEWS|access-date=March 30, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200330004919/https://apnews.com/e96aea5d3a1d9dd2c27ebeb88a61df28|archive-date=March 30, 2020|url-status=live}} She moved from Ireland to Nashville in 1993, and they were married in 1996. Prine and Whelan had two sons together, Jack and [[Tommy Prine|Tommy]], and Prine adopted Whelan's son, Jody, from a previous relationship.{{Cite web|url=https://www.latimes.com/entertainment-arts/music/story/2020-04-08/john-prine-wife-fiona-whelan-prine-reaction|title=John Prine's Widow Mourns his Death from COVID-19|last=D'Zurilla|first=Christie|date=April 8, 2020|website=Los Angeles Times|access-date=April 10, 2020}} Prine had a home, and spent part of the year, in [[Kinvara]], Galway, Ireland. === Health problems === In early 1998, Prine was diagnosed with [[Squamous cell carcinoma|squamous-cell cancer]] on the right side of his neck. He had major surgery to remove a substantial amount of diseased tissue, followed by six weeks of [[radiation therapy]].{{cite web |url=http://www.jpshrine.org/john_prine_letter.html |title=John Prine personal letter to his fans about his cancer |website=Jpshrine.org |access-date=March 15, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101125221035/http://jpshrine.org/john_prine_letter.html |archive-date=November 25, 2010 |url-status=live }} The surgery removed a piece of his neck and severed a few nerves in his tongue, while the radiation damaged some [[salivary glands]]. A year of recuperation and [[speech therapy]] were necessary before he could perform again.{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/10/arts/music/john-prine-endures-with-a-half-smile-and-a-song.html | title=John Prine Endures, With a Half-Smile and a Song | newspaper=[[The New York Times]] | date=April 6, 2016 | access-date=May 10, 2018 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180511015019/https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/10/arts/music/john-prine-endures-with-a-half-smile-and-a-song.html | archive-date=May 11, 2018 | url-status=live }} The operation altered his vocals and added a gravelly tone to his voice.[http://home.mchsi.com/~rburhead/2005/05concertreviews_IL.htm John Prine concert reviews] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110526024957/http://home.mchsi.com/~rburhead/2005/05concertreviews_IL.htm |date=May 26, 2011 }} June 4, 2005 In 2013, Prine underwent surgery to remove [[Lung cancer|cancer in his left lung]]. After the surgery, a physical therapist put him through an unusual workout to build stamina: Prine was required to run up and down his house stairs, grab his guitar while still out of breath, and sing two songs. Six months later, he was touring again. === Death === On March 19, 2020, amid [[COVID-19 pandemic|the COVID-19 pandemic]] [[COVID-19 pandemic in the United States|in the United States]], Prine's wife Fiona revealed that she had tested positive for [[Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2|SARS-CoV-2]] and had been [[quarantined]] in their home apart from him.{{Cite web|url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/music/news/john-prine-in-critical-condition-after-hospitalization-for-coronavirus/ar-BB11SC6n|title=John Prine in Critical Condition After Hospitalization for lyrical wishes, expressed in his song "[[Paradise (John Prine song)|Paradise]]", half of his ashes were spread in Kentucky's [[Green River (Kentucky)|Green River]].Dyer, Diane (September 13, 2022). ''[[WLBQ|BeechTree News]]''. Retrieved September 15, 2022.[https://beechtreenews.com/articles/john-prine-memorial-park "John Prine Memorial Park"]. ''[[WLBQ|BeechTree News]]''. October 4, 2022. Retrieved October 7, 2022. The other half were buried next to his parents in Chicago.{{Cite magazine |last1=Doyle |first1=Patrick |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/john-prine-last-days-beautiful-life-tribute-family-friends-bonnie-raitt-981646/ |title=John Prine: The Last Days and Beautiful Life of an American Original |date=April 13, 2020 |magazine=Rolling Stone |access-date=April 16, 2020 |language=en-US}} == Influence == Prine is widely regarded as one of the most influential songwriters of his generation.{{cite news |last1=Pond |first1=Steve |title=John Prine, Revered Singer-Songwriter, Dies at 73 From Coronavirus |url=https://www.thewrap.com/john-prine-dies-73-coronavirus/ |access-date=April 7, 2020 |work=The Wrap |date=April 7, 2020 |quote=John Prine, one of the most influential and revered folk and country songwriters of the last 50 years and an unassuming man who was still producing quality work after two bouts with cancer, has died at the age of 73 after being infected with the COVID-19 virus ... through two dozen albums over nearly 40 years, Prine remained a hugely influential songwriter who was held in high esteem by his peers in folk and country music. |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200408030821/https://www.thewrap.com/john-prine-dies-73-coronavirus/ |archive-date=April 8, 2020 |url-status=live }}{{cite news |last1=Barry |first1=Dan |title=John Prine Endures, With a Half-Smile and a Song |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/10/arts/music/john-prine-endures-with-a-half-smile-and-a-song.html |access-date=April 7, 2020 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=April 6, 2016 |quote=Many tough days have been made better by Mr. Prine, the influential singer and songwriter with a gift for articulating moments almost beyond words. His songs have won the respect of Johnny Cash, Kris Kristofferson, Pink Floyd, the Library of Congress, you name it. One admirer, Bob Dylan, once described his canon as 'pure Proustian existentialism' and 'Midwestern mind trips to the nth degree.' |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200408035332/https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/10/arts/music/john-prine-endures-with-a-half-smile-and-a-song.html |archive-date=April 8, 2020 |url-status=live }}{{cite news |last1=Beaumont-Thomas |first1=Ben |title=John Prine, US folk and country songwriter, dies aged 73 due to Covid-19 complications |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2020/apr/08/john-prine-us-folk-and-country-songwriter-dies-aged-73 |access-date=April 7, 2020 |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=April 7, 2020 |quote='We join the world in mourning the passing of revered country and folk singer/songwriter John Prine,' the Recording Academy said in a written statement. 'Widely lauded as one of the most influential songwriters of his generation, John's impact will continue to inspire musicians for years to come. We send our deepest condolences to his loved ones.' |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200408020634/https://www.theguardian.com/music/2020/apr/08/john-prine-us-folk-and-country-songwriter-dies-aged-73 |archive-date=April 8, 2020 |url-status=live }} He has been referred to as "the [[Mark Twain]] of songwriting".{{Cite magazine |last=Doyle |first=Patrick |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/inside-the-life-of-john-prine-the-mark-twain-of-american-songwriting-115459/ |title=Inside the Life of John Prine, the Mark Twain of American Songwriting |date=January 4, 2017 |magazine=Rolling Stone |access-date=April 9, 2020 |language=en-US}}{{Cite news |last=Leimkuehler |first=Matthew |url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2020/04/07/john-prine-obituary-singer-songwriter-covid-19/1807915001/ |title=John Prine, the Mark Twain of modern songwriting, dies at age 73 |work=Nashville Tennessean |access-date=April 9, 2020 |language=en-US |via=USA Today}} [[Bob Dylan]] named Prine one of his favorite songwriters in 2009. He remarked, "Prine's stuff is pure [[Marcel Proust|Proustian]] [[existentialism]]. [[Midwestern]] mindtrips to the nth degree. And he writes beautiful songs. All that stuff about '[[Sam Stone (song)|Sam Stone]]', the soldier junkie daddy, and 'Donald and Lydia', where people make love from ten miles away. Nobody but Prine could write like that."{{cite news |last=Flanagan |first=Bill |date=April 15, 2009 |title=Bob Dylan Exclusive Interview: Reveals His Favorite Songwriters, Thoughts On His Own Cult Figure Status |work=[[HuffPost|Huffington Post]] |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/04/15/bob-dylan-exclusive-inter_n_187216.html |url-status=live |access-date=July 12, 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090722235252/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/04/15/bob-dylan-exclusive-inter_n_187216.html |archive-date=July 22, 2009}} [[Johnny Cash]], in his autobiography ''[[Cash: The Autobiography|Cash]]'', wrote, "I don't listen to music much at the farm, unless I'm going into songwriting mode and looking for inspiration. Then I'll put on something by the writers I've admired and used for years—[[Rodney Crowell]], John Prine, [[Guy Clark]], and the late [[Steve Goodman]] are my Big Four ..."{{cite book|last1=Cash|first1=Johnny |first2=Patrick |last2=Carr |title=Cash: The Autobiography|publisher=[[HarperCollins]]|year=2003|page=189|isbn= 9780060727536|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yL6MRZfrWjkC}} [[Roger Waters]], when asked by ''[[Word Magazine]]'' in 2008 if he heard [[Pink Floyd]]'s influence in newer British bands such as [[Radiohead]], replied, "I don't really listen to Radiohead. I listened to the albums and they just didn't move me in the way, say, John Prine does. His is just extraordinarily eloquent music—and he lives on that plane with [[Neil Young|Neil [Young]]] and [[John Lennon|[John] Lennon]]."{{cite web|url=http://www.wordmagazine.co.uk/content/word-exclusive-roger-waters|title=Word Interview Exclusive: Roger Waters|work=Word Magazine|date=April 13, 2008|access-date=July 12, 2009|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081024104158/http://www.wordmagazine.co.uk/content/word-exclusive-roger-waters|archive-date=October 24, 2008}} He later named Prine as among the five most important songwriters.{{cite web|url=https://faroutmagazine.co.uk/roger-waters-fice-favourite-songwriters/|title=Pink Floyd's Roger Waters picks his five favourite songwriters of all time|work=Far Out Magazine|date=Oct 29, 2021|access-date=Nov 14, 2021}} Prine's influence is seen in the work of younger artists, whom he often mentored, including [[Jason Isbell]], [[Amanda Shires]], [[Brandi Carlile]], [[Sturgill Simpson]], [[Kacey Musgraves]], [[Margo Price]], [[Tyler Childers]], and [[Robin Pecknold]].{{Cite news |last=Vain |first=Madison |url=https://www.esquire.com/entertainment/music/a32079472/john-prine-tribute-obit-bio-essay/ |title=John Prine Was Always There. The World Didn't Know How Lucky It Was. |date=April 8, 2020 |work=Esquire |access-date=April 12, 2020 |language=en-US}}{{Cite web|last=Bobkin|first=Matt|date=September 22, 2020|title=Fleet Foxes Explain the Terrifying Near-Death Experience That Ushered in Their Joyful New Chapter|url=http://exclaim.ca/music/article/fleet_foxes_shore_surprise_album_release_interview|website=Exclaim}} == Awards and honors == === Grammy Awards === Prine won four [[Grammy Awards]] out of 13 nominations, as well as a [[Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award]].{{cite web|url=https://www.grammy.com/grammys/artists/john-prine|title=John Prine|publisher=[[The Recording Academy]]|website=grammy.com|access-date=March 30, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190325190653/https://www.grammy.com/grammys/artists/john-prine|archive-date=March 25, 2019|url-status=live}} {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" |+Grammy Awards and nominations for John Prine |- ! scope="row" |2021 | [[Grammy Award for Best American Roots Song|Best American Roots Song]] | {{won}} |} ===Other accolades=== *In 2005, at the request of [[United States Poet Laureate|U.S. Poet Laureate]] [[Ted Kooser]], John Prine became the first singer-songwriter to read and perform at the [[Library of Congress]].{{cite web|url=https://www.loc.gov/today/cyberlc/feature_wdesc.php?rec=3677|title=A Literary Evening with John Prine and Ted Kooser|publisher=[[Library of Congress]]|date=March 9, 2005|access-date=May 22, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180728051442/http://www.loc.gov/today/cyberlc/feature_wdesc.php?rec=3677|archive-date=July 28, 2018|url-status=live}} *In 2016, Prine received the [[PEN International|PEN]] New England Song Lyrics of Literary Excellence Award. *In 2019, Prine was inducted into the [[Songwriters Hall of Fame]] with a speech by [[Bonnie Raitt]].{{Cite news |last=Hughes |first=Hillary |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/9356507/bonnie-raitt-dedicates-home-john-prine |title=Bonnie Raitt Comforts With Home Tribute for John Prine |date=April 11, 2020 |access-date=April 12, 2020}} *Over his career, Prine received six awards from the [[Americana Music Honors & Awards]]: the Lifetime Achievement Award for Songwriting (2003), Artist of the Year (2005, 2017, 2018), Song of the Year for "Summer's End" (2019), and Album of the Year for ''[[The Tree of Forgiveness]]'' (2019). *On June 30, 2020, Illinois's Governor [[J. B. Pritzker]] posthumously named Prine the honorary [[Poets Laureate of Illinois|Poet Laureate of Illinois]].{{cite magazine |url= https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/john-prine-illinois-honorary-poet-laureate-1023021/ |title= John Prine Named Illinois' First Honorary Poet Laureate |last1= Kreps |first1= Daniel |date= 1 July 2020 |magazine= [[Rolling Stone]] |publisher= [[Penske Media Corporation]] |access-date= 12 December 2020}} *The John Prine Songwriter Fellowship was created in Prine's honor. In 2022, [[Leith Ross (singer)|Leith Ross]] became the first recipient.{{Cite web |last=Swain |first=Dan |date=2022-04-27 |title=Newport Festivals Announces 2022 Prine Songwriter Fellowship Winner - Newport Festivals Foundation |url=https://newportfestivals.org/prine-fellowship-2022,%20https://newportfestivals.org/prine-fellowship-2022 |access-date=2023-03-28 |website=newportfestivals.org |language=en-US}} == Discography == The week after his death, Prine hit number one on ''Billboard''{{'}}s Rock Songwriters Chart because his singles ("In Spite Of Ourselves", "Angel from Montgomery", "Hello In There", "When I Get To Heaven", and "That's the Way the World Goes Round") all charted in the top 25 of the Hot Rock Song Chart.
